snippet: The coroner said it was unlikely that the case would ever be resolved, and played down suggestions that facets of Gareth Williams’s private life had led to his death.
abstract: Coroner in London says the death of Gareth Williams, a Welsh-born mathematician involved in top-secret code-breaking work for MI6, found doubled up inside a padlocked duffel bag in his London flat, is unlikely to be solved; suggests that he was unlawfully killed and that some third party was involved. (M)
lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Deepening the mystery surrounding the death of a reclusive MI6 agent found doubled up inside a padlocked duffel bag in his London flat, a coroner said on Wednesday that it was unlikely that the case would ever be solved, but that the ''balance of probabilities'' suggested that he had been unlawfully killed. Scotland Yard reacted immediately by saying it would continue its efforts to hunt down the killer. After an eight-day inquest that has thrown an uncomfortable spotlight on MI6, Britain's secret intelligence service, the coroner, Dr. Fiona Wilcox, said the death of Gareth Williams, 31, a Welsh-born mathematician involved in top-secret code-breaking work, appeared to have been ''unnatural and likely to have been criminally mediated.'' That meant he was either killed or was assisted in a suicide plot.

headline.main: Foul Play Ruled Likely In Case of Spy Found Dead
